images.copyright: Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, New York City (© Jonathan Orenstein/Getty Images)
images.title: Rockefeller 'round the Christmas tree
images.caption: Rockefeller Centre Christmas tree lighting
images.desc: As December approaches, New York gears up for a sparkling spectacle. Mark a big star on your calendar for November 29 because the 91st Rockefeller Centre Tree Lighting will bring you festive vibes. The towering Norway spruce, as seen, is adorned with over 50,000 multicoloured LED lights and topped with a Swarovski crystal star. Just wait until the giant tree—up to 30 metres high—is illuminated; it is a full-blown extravaganza with musical performances and celebrity sightings.

og.title: Rockefeller Centre Christmas tree lighting
og.desc: As December approaches, New York gears up for a sparkling spectacle. Mark a big star on your calendar for November 29 because the 91st…

images.copyright: Giant land art fresco by artist Saype in Istanbul, Türkiye (© Chris McGrath/Getty Images)
images.title: A day to lend a hand
images.caption: Giving Tuesday
images.desc: As we get caught up in the hustle and bustle of gift shopping and festive decorations, it's time to remember the true spirit of times like these: generosity and kindness. That's where Giving Tuesday comes in. This annual holiday, which falls on the first Tuesday after Thanksgiving in the US, was initiated by the United Nations Foundation and New York's 92nd Street Y—a cultural organisation and community center—over ten years ago. Their vision was to make a difference by providing joy to everyone through acts of charity. Generosity is something we can all practice, and there are many ways to become involved, such as volunteering at a local non-profit organisation, shelter, or food bank, donating to a charity, or simply giving a voice to people in need in your community. So, let's jump on board with the millions of kind souls, shake hands, and share warm wishes far and wide!
images.bsTitle: A day to lend a hand

og.title: Giving Tuesday
og.desc: As we get caught up in the hustle and bustle of gift shopping and festive decorations, it's time to remember the true spirit of times like…

images.copyright: Río Negro, Amazon basin, Brazil (© Timothy Allen/Getty Images)
images.title: Mirror, mirror, on the water
images.caption: Río Negro, Amazon basin, Brazil
images.desc: The Río Negro, originating in Colombia, is one of dozens of tributaries that flow into the massive Amazon River. Its name, which means black river, comes from its dark appearance when viewed from a distance. As a result, the water can reflect the colourful hues of the sky overhead, such as the vibrant blue and partial rainbow seen here. The colour of the river comes from the high concentration of humic acid, thanks to decomposing organic matter that seeps from nearby swamps. As one of the largest northern-bank tributaries of the Amazon River, the Río Negro plays a crucial role in the complex Amazon basin ecosystem. The river is home to many plants and animals, including the critically endangered Brazilian barefaced tamarin, the giant river otter, and nearly 700 species of fish.

og.title: Río Negro, Amazon basin, Brazil
og.desc: The Río Negro, originating in Colombia, is one of dozens of tributaries that flow into the massive Amazon River. Its name, which means black…

images.copyright: Fallow deer in Bradgate Park, Leicestershire, England (© Chris Bainbridge/Alamy)
images.title: Who stepped on a twig?
images.caption: Fallow deer, Bradgate Park, Leicestershire, England
images.desc: Fallow deer are known for their striking coat, which changes colour with the seasons and is often adorned with white spots in the summer. During the autumn rutting season, males spar with each other to establish their dominance. These male deer can be spotted by their palmate antlers, which have a broad, flattened surface. Fallow deer are native to Europe and parts of Asia and are a common sight in Leicestershire, England, particularly in Bradgate Park. This 3.4-square-kilometre park not only offers a sanctuary for these animals but also features beautiful landscapes, woodlands, and the Beacon Hill Tower, which offers panoramic views of the area.

og.title: Fallow deer, Bradgate Park, Leicestershire, England
og.desc: Fallow deer are known for their striking coat, which changes colour with the seasons and is often adorned with white spots in the summer…

images.copyright: Mount Logan in Kluane National Park and Reserve, Yukon, Canada (© A. Michael Brown/Shutterstock)
images.title: Kluane's untamed beauty
images.caption: Kluane National Park and Reserve, Yukon
images.desc: Kluane National Park and Reserve of the Yukon beckons adventurers with its untamed beauty and plentiful peaks. Its story began millions of years ago when Mighty glaciers sculpted its landscape millions of years ago, and the federal government established Kluane National Park and Reserve in 1976. The park's most precious jewel is Canada's highest peak, Mount Logan, a towering sentinel that challenges climbers. The history of this UNESCO World Heritage Site intertwines with the culture of the Champagne and Aishihik First Nations, who have called this area home for centuries. Visitors who venture here can embark on a journey through ancient forests, navigate crystal-clear lakes, and witness the grandeur of glaciers.

og.title: Kluane National Park and Reserve, Yukon
og.desc: Kluane National Park and Reserve of the Yukon beckons adventurers with its untamed beauty and plentiful peaks. Its story began millions of…

images.copyright: Hall of Mosses trail in the Hoh Rain Forest, Olympic National Park, Washington (© James Randklev/Getty Images)
images.title: A different kind of rainforest
images.caption: Green Friday
images.desc: Imagine spending the day hiking in a forest, soaking in the lush greenery, instead of frantically checking every item off your holiday shopping list. Welcome to Green Friday, the environmental alternative to Black Friday, established in 2015. On Green Friday, people are encouraged to approach shopping by making ethical choices, embracing nature, or refraining from purchasing altogether. So, take a pause for a moment and plunge yourself into nature this Green Friday!

og.title: Green Friday
og.desc: Imagine spending the day hiking in a forest, soaking in the lush greenery, instead of frantically checking every item off your holiday…

images.copyright: Sunset at Teide National Park, Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain (© Javier Martínez Morán/Alamy)
images.title: Summits in the sea
images.caption: Teide National Park, Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain
images.desc: Exploring the history of Teide National Park, one of the Twelve Treasures of Spain, is like taking off on a captivating journey through time. This UNESCO World Heritage Site, established around scenic Mount Teide on the Spanish Canary Island of Tenerife, has a rich past. Its volcanic origins date back millions of years, creating not only the terrain of the park but the entire island. The indigenous Guanche people believed that Teide was the gate to hell. This location has served as the backdrop for movies like 'Fast and Furious 6', 'Rambo V: Last Blood', and 'Clash of the Titans' (2010). If you are planning to visit this amazing place, make sure you enjoy the coach trips through the park, and if you wish to enjoy the view from the peak, then remember to get the permit in advance.

og.title: Teide National Park, Tenerife, Canary Islands, Spain
og.desc: Exploring the history of Teide National Park, one of the Twelve Treasures of Spain, is like taking off on a captivating journey through time…

images.copyright: Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming (© Westend61/Getty Images)
images.title: Big on beauty, short on people
images.caption: Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming
images.desc: Today's image gives us a glimpse of beautiful Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming. The park, established in 1929, includes numerous lakes, the Snake River, and the Teton Range, famed for its series of sharp, jagged peaks. Bring your binoculars with you, and if it's summertime, be on the lookout for pronghorns, who travel about 240 kilometres to get there. They aren't the only creatures to visit seasonally; elk and bison are also summer visitors. These migrations play a vital role in the ecosystem of Grand Teton National Park. The animals help disperse seeds and provide food for predators.
images.bsTitle: Big on beauty, short on people
